engage.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to be doing or to become involved in an activity
engage.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Only 10% of American adults engage in regular exercise.
The two parties engaged upon an escalating political struggle.
Mr Armstrong was engaged in prayer.
Despite her illness, she remains actively engaged in shaping policy.
engage.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to attract someone’s attention and keep them interested
engage.translation[0].definitions[1].not: engage somebody in conversation (=start talking to them)
engage.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The toy didn’t engage her interest for long.
engage.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to employ someone to do a particular job
engage.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Her father engaged a tutor to improve her maths.
We’d be able to engage local people as volunteers.
engage.translation[0].definitions[3].def: if you engage part of a machine, or if it engages, it moves so that it fits into another part of the machine
engage.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: She engaged the clutch and the car moved.
The wheel engages with the cog and turns it.
engage.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to begin to fight an enemy
engage.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: American forces did not directly engage.
engage.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to arrange to employ someone or to pay someone to do something for you
engage.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: You will need to engage a commercial lawyer to protect your interests in the drafting of a contract.
